As you may know, Governor J.B. Pritzker announced on April 17 that all Illinois schools are ordered to remain closed for the remainder of the 2019-20 school year. Remote learning resumed yesterday and we will continue to follow our remote learning plan for the remainder of the school year. I wish I could speak to you all in person, but tried to express some of what we are feeling in this video message.

Like you, it comes with great disappointment to recognize we will not be able to come together with our students for the remainder of the school year. This is not the end of the school year that we envisioned. Our senior class has been dealt a distinctly tough hand. They have worked incredibly hard for the past four years to achieve and celebrate their countless accomplishments completed during their high school career. We are actively investigating a number of possibilities and alternatives to hold graduation, prom and end-of-career events, including having virtual events to celebrate our graduating class and retirees.

Read more at: http://www.rich227.org/COVID-19Updates.aspx

Congratulations to the Rich Township FIRST Robot Competition (FRC) Team!

Our students came together from all three campuses to build a robot in 8 weeks and competed in the Midwest Regional 2020 tournament against teams from across the nation and globe, including teams from Mexico and Turkey!

The students placed 29th out of 54 and were the 2nd highest ranked Rookie team - to finish this high as a Rookie team is an amazing feat!

If you would like to see the matches, you can search YouTube for "Midwest Regional 2020 8160". Midwest Regional 2020 is the event and 8160 is the team number. They were in Qualification matches 1, 15, 24, 33, 44, 50, 69, 75, and 82.

Here's the link for Qualification 1: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SJumKITUM4k

"Here at Rich Central High School in the South Suburbs of #Chicago, Ms. Argue was my Junior year English Teacher. I walked into this classroom shy and insecure, not knowing that I would walk out with purpose and hope. After having our class write a poem for a homework assignment, then recite it in front of the class, Ms. Argue pulled me to the side, she gave me an “A,” then proceeded to ask me to perform at an upcoming talent show. I was too scared to do the show, but Ms. Argue approached me again and “made” me do the next show. As nervous as I was, I performed and surprisingly got a standing ovation my first time ever on stage. Needless to say I’ve been performing ever since. Ms. Argue forever changed my life. Teachers change lives! Love You Ms. Argue." - J. Ivy, #RecordingAcademy Chicago Chapter President and spoken word artist.

Support music education and celebrate educators throughout the month of March: grm.my/2TvQ7gn #MarchForMusicEd 🎶📚
